Wishing you smooth sailing......  Joanne
Posts.Title: Port Question AO44 Areyousure

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2007 01:08PM joanne1428 wrote: What I did is that I completed each of my kids "school" scrapbooks, with the life parts of those years woven in....  I ran out of physical strength for this project, but my sister stepped in to help me finish. I've done a few more things that were important to me, such as: -  a heritage cookbook, with family recipes and what my food related memories are - I would still like to hand-write more recipes out though -  I recorded a CD with me reading favourite children's stories and meditations that I used to read to them when they were small and could not sleep - I divided up all my jewelry for my kids, nieces, nephews and put that and a handwritten card into a lovely gift fabric bag.... - I completed a "My Personal Legacy" booklet that our palliative team helped me to put together, and it basically was guided journalling with me answering questions about my life, what I believed in, what advice I would give, etc... - I've cross-stitched a graduation picture for each, along with an "inspirational" quote that means something to me.... they are all framed and ready to go...... also, I've made a cross-stitch wedding sampler for each, although someone else will have to personalize and frame it..... for those gifts I also wrote out cards to go with those occaisions.  - I've made several cross-stich samplers/sayings for my friends as well. - I wish I had some talent other than the cross-stitch, but that is it, and so I have also cross stitched some baby bibs to be saved and given out to future grandchildren. - I made "worry stone" thumbprints out of clay - something that could be tucked into a pocket on a tough day........ I have not bought gifts for every occasion ahead, because that just felt too overwhelming.... To be honest, I had started doing some of this on my own, but the music therapist and social worker through my palliative care (hospice) program, have helped me do a few things I never would have thought of on my own, and it does bring me peace. Also, I'm not stopping, it's pretty well what I devote my time too - making gifts and keepsakes for my friends and family members....  I would also love to totally go through all of my possessions and divvy it up and then throw the rest away so that my husband and children do not have to do this task, but I don't think I have the physical ability to do that right now..... For now, it is stiching, and I am a stitching demon.......  Too bad cross-stitch is apparently "out of style"  and a decorating no-no, (hee hee) cuz my loved ones are getting a bunch of it........... Love reading the other ideas, please keep them coming !!!!

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2007 10:43AM - edited Oct 3, 2007 10:43AM by joanne1428 Well, thanks so much for asking.  I'm so much better than I was when I took the nosedive downhill in the summer.... but..... I am only what I would call sort of stable.....  I am at home, but still mostly in bed, on oxygen and on morphine.... but apart from that, most of my symptoms are managed and I live the most engaged life that I can from my little hospital bed!  My scans are indeed showing very gradual improvement, not sure what I can expect in the future - so, what I am doing is trying super hard to just remain in the present and in this moment, and at least this present moment is crisis free! I have a feeling this report sounds a little depressing, but believe me, I am still holding bundles of hope, and I just try to sqeeze on to that with all my might!  You ladies here help me a great deal to hold on to that hope, you have a very powerfully good influence on me !!! Cheers to all - Joanne - Thanks for asking about me.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2007 12:57AM joanne1428 wrote: Lanef, I am so sorry you are going through all of this with your mom, this disease can indeed be very brutal. I have been on Cisplatin (a cousin to Carboplatin) and it was managable to me, with the anti-nausea meds they give.  However, I was 44 at the time and it was my first line treatment for lung mets.... so I was relatively "healthy" Since that time I have been on several chemos, some have worked better than others, but I have never had more than a partial response.  I have had malignant pleural effusion and unfortunately when I had it drained (a relatively routine procedure) something went wrong and my lower left lung collapsed, causing me lots of pain and sudden lessening of my lung function.  Chemo, oxygen, morphine and bedrest have worked to get me back into a relatively good state, although my functional mobility is very low..... My quality of life (as long as i stay in bed) is decent.  There are a lot of ups and downs in this disease.  Chemo has worked to lessen the effusion.  I'm not sure why your mom would have an effusion if not for lung mets, but I would ask before assuming, you never know with this disease. As for your mom's wanting to make her plans, I can imagine how difficult it is for you to particiate, but if you can, it will be a real gift to your mom.  Most of us here have -to some degree- made some plans and worked on some legacy type things..... sort of planning for the worst, but hoping for the best.  I've been doing it slowly, as I've been emotionally ready, bit by bit.  I had a priest sit down with my mom, my husband and myself and planned out my funeral, I've been deciding on gifts, writing letters, recording some CDs for my kids.    Your mom will have more peace if she feels like you are going to be "ok".... I know that's what I want for my kids who are 21, 19 and 15.  I know it is going to be terrible and horrible to lose a mother, I just want to feel like they will get through.  I have gone so far as to ask certain of my friends to check on each of my children and my hubby, kind of assigned a watchdog to each......  It brings me a bit of comfort.....Even though it is on the bizarre side, being present while she vocalizes her wishes likely brings her peace, and that is a big gift to her if you are able to give it. Again, I am so sorry you have to be dealing with this, it is amessy, uncivilized disease.  But while the "worst" is a possibility, never forget that there is still lots of hope, all things are possible and a few months from now, the situation could be reversed for the positive.  Always reasons to hope.     Take care - Joanne
Posts.Title: WHAT DOES IT MEAN WHEN THEY DRAIN THE LUNGS? LANEF Maya1

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2007 02:29PM joanne1428 wrote: Carol:  RE:  your question about hospice. A few months ago, and rather suddenly, I took a serious nose-dive downhill.  Something went awry during a routine attempt to drain a pleural effusion and my right lower lung collapsed.  Suddenly, I was placed on morphine and  on oxygen and I was being referred for homecare nursing - for a hospital bed to be put in my home, etc.  All of a sudden I was very very sick. The social worker at the cancer clinic asked me if I was open to her making a palliative home care referral, or did I only want regular homecare.  After a great huge deal of SHOCK at the word "Palliative" (I didn't want it to be "time" for that yet !!!) I figured out  that I would get much better service on the palliative service than the regular, so I swallowed my pride and agreed to the palliative/hospice service. Best decision I ever made.  The truth is I am Stage IV and although I do not consider myself to be "dying" at the moment, I have all the expected issues in dealing with a life threatening disease.  Their team has just done so much to help me (and my family) cope with everything that it is just amazing.  I utilize a social worker, a music therapist, a spiritual care counsellor, OT, and the nursing care - I can't say enough about everything they do for me, but I'd be happy to give more info if anyone is interested.  Plus, they are just so skilled at dealing with the big "D" issue, they just know how to talk about it without being freaky, or at least that is my experience. It was the only good thing that came out of my little medical crisis.  I'm still in the hospital bed, still on oxygen and morphine, but I'm not planning on going anywhere soon, and they support me in that goal too.   They know I want every single day I can squeeze out of this deal, and they support me in that, but at the same time they help me plan for "the end" whenever that may be. Hope that bit of info helps....Joanne

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2007 01:22PM joanne1428 wrote: Gee Minette, I sort of remembered posts in response to your question, I might have answered myself (now my memory is foggy!) I hope you really enjoy your chemo break.  As I remember, your oncologist wasn't all that enthusiastic about it, and you were asking us for signs of progression?  Perhaps we weren't able to provide you with the answers you seek, partly because breast cancer is so sneaky.  None of us can tell you one way or the other whether you should take a break, if your cancer will stay stable, or even what it might feel like if it keeps growing.  I know for myself... I have often had progression on my scans at times when I thought I was doing great....  for me it seems like the disease progresses in advance of any visible symptom.  That's why I am hesitant of giving advice about it! I am also thinking of taking a chemo break over Christmas, but I still haven't decided, I am terribly UNDECIDED in fact.  Weighting out the pros and cons, but I'm having a tough time.  In the end, I guess we each must do what is right for us, in our unique circumstance.   Right now I don't even know what is right for ME, so I feel very stupid trying to give suggestions to others! I am lucky because I am on disability and do not have to factor in an unreasonable boss.... I sure hope that your boss settles in to a more consistently supportive person. Minette, you have said several times that you feel really stressed and it does seem like you have a lot on your plate.  Maybe your nurse has made a good suggestion about seeing someone while you are on your chemo break to discuss your decision, your life in general and your stresses, see if there is anything that you could do to ease the burden or ways in which your family could lighten your load.  I hope you find some of these solutions and I hope you have a ton of happiness and peace during your chemo break.  Joanne

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 11:29PM joanne1428 wrote: Hi Alice,  I have had lung mets since April 06.  The prognosis depends very much on the pathology of the cancer.  I have "triple negative" cancer, which  means that chemo is really my only treatment option. I've only been told a typical prognosis once (because I specifically asked) and I'm pretty sure it would not be helpful to mention it again, here or anywhere.  Prognosis stats are something that depend on so much and they are also outdated, many oncologists are reluctant to even say, since they are so often wrong. It does sound to me like your mom has plenty of time to have that reconstruction with no ill effects on possible mets treatment, but of course, in the end that is up to her.  And it is no matter of vanity for sure, it is a unique decision that is different for each of us.  Still hoping for your mom that the further scans will show benign nodules - keep hope burning bright, it does happen!!! Joanne

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2007 02:02AM joanne1428 wrote: Waiting and wondering is one of the horrible aspects of this disease and I'm not sure any of us ever get used to it, although I think we all get a little bit better at it.  It is exceptionally stressful and I think you have to do all the usual things you do to manage stress, and when that is not enough perhaps ask your own family physician for a bit of help - the odd Ativan goes a long way when things seem spinning out of control. I imagine that your mom's doc thinks it is reasonable to go ahead with reconstructive surgery, since getting a PET will take awhile anyway - to get the scan and WAIT for results, etc...  If indeed it is lung mets, it sounds like the amount of disease is TINY, and so I don't think that having the reconstructive surgery would cause her risk with any treatment she might need, although if she does need chemo, it would delay it somewhat. I have lung mets and mediastinel lymph node mets, which I developed 5 yrs after being treated for Stage 1 bc,  and I am 46 years old.   I have never had reconstructive surgery for my mastectomy, and to be honest it just isn't a big deal for me.  So personally, I would NOT put my energy there right now if it were me.....  HOWEVER, the reconstruction may be really important to your mom and one of the biggest ways we support each other in this journey is to be respectful of each person's goals and wishes.  One thing I do know from my heart is how much your support must mean to your mom at this difficult time.   She will let you know by her words and actions what will be the most helpful thing for her, but your support is a true gift.  Bless you both while you wait in this agonizing time. Joanne

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2007 11:50AM joanne1428 wrote: Rose, I think you have nailed the heart of the dilemna with cancer drugs.... We know from the start that they are not effective on everyone, but we don't yet know quite who.... so we all want them, to be "covered"... I know I did. You just have to look at Avastin now.... we all want it (me included) because of early results that looked like a miracle.    Now that the reality emerges and it is another drug with pros and cons, but not necessarily one that will be real good OR be cost effective, it may not get FDA approval, or approval in Canada where I live.  But I still want to try it because, maybe, just maybe, I'll be one of those miracle results......  WE can't help ourselves.  We choose with our hearts and our guts and we do not want to be denyed our chance.....  It seems to me that we should remember that several years down the road when we either end up like me, with the drugs NOT working.... OR when the longer term survivors (Hooray) might develop some of the serious side effects from these heavy hitter drugs..... It's a pickle...... I know for one that I have been fully informed all along about risks and benefits, including response rates to all the chemos I have been on.  News of poor effectiveness does not come as a shock to me.......I was NEVER told "take this and you will be fine".... but maybe the medical world has to make darn sure that we all receive highy informed information so that we are honestly consenting to whatever the treatment is - good, bad and the ugly.  Joanne

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2007 12:42PM - edited Sep 28, 2007 12:42PM by joanne1428 There is definitely no "list".... here is where the "art" of oncology enters and the real skill of the oncologist is tested.  They go by the unique pathology of your disease, your current state of health/disease, and your overall health (which tx you can tolerate) current literature, their own practice successes, your preferences (such as "no hair loss") and i think to a certain extent, their "Gut".  Here's my list: 2001 - 4 AC for node negative IDC 2004 - 6 Taxotere for chest wall recurrence 2006 - 6 Cisplatin + Gemzar cycles for lung/mediastinel nodes            (excellent initial response, then "stable", then progression)          - 4 round Xeloda (it FAILED spectacularly)          - currenly on Cisplatin + Myocet (liposome encapsulated doxyrubicn) with excellent partial response, but still a long way to go! They figure my heart can take maybe 2 more of these before needing to switch to another drug, am having ANOTHER MUGA to be sure.... Good luck, looks like you have access to some real cutting edge trials and options.  Getting two years from your last chemo is incredible in my books !!!! I have always wanted to find a trial, but have never been eligible at the time I need it.  Best of luck - Joanne

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2008 04:42AM joanne1428 wrote: Deb, I think that for me, one of the "secrets" to coping, is that there is no secret to coping.    This is one huge honker of a think to cope with.  And while it might happen to some people - reaching peace, etc........  It just isn't going to happen to me.   I cannot find peace leaving my husband and three children behind ages 21-19-16, they are just learning to stretch their wings.   Telling them was the worst moment of my life, right after telling them about diagnosis #1.  As I remember, you are triple negative, and I am happy to tell you that there are a few more options for you, then there for me, even 2 years ago.   Mostly the clinical trials, the PARP and other inhibitors.   Not much in the mainstream I'm afraid.    Still... it is grim, to be triple negative, to know that chemo is the only option....   AND I remember that you are one savvy lady in terms of your own research you have doe on this disease.   On the boards even, you will see how happy people are just to have "bone" or just to use hormonals......   oh how weird this disease can be. Anyway, to your question... there is no road map, just you, trying to put one foot in front of the next.    And there will be many people here and elsewhere to help... at this point, let them.... TAKE all those pharmaceuticals, what's the point of sufferening?     Get a treatment plan in place, then you will have an iota of "control" if there is such a thing.... but mostly, you will have some much emotion that you also need something "fixed" to think about , like getting that chemo underway so you can blast that cancer to bits.... I wish this had not happened to you Deb.   Sending lots of love, Joanne

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2007 12:09AM - edited Nov 16, 2007 12:11AM by joanne1428 I've had two ports inserted with no problems.......however a friend of mine had her port infected, and she was so fed up of the horrible infection, pain and antibiotics, no way was she going to get another... she got a PICC line and was just fine with it..... only thing is, that was just for six treatments.... For me, with my "chemo until forever" treatment reality, I think I would chance another port insertion,  I kind of doubt your body rejected it, they are stainless steel, so the odds woudl be low (although you never know).... I think it was probably just one of those bad surgical outcomes that should  never happen.....  something technique wise must have gone wrong to have introduced infection.  Do you know your surgeon's record and experience with port insertions?  Some are experts, putting in dozens regularly, others just once in awhile, it might be relevent and something to ask about.  Surgeons should not be offended by enquiries related to their success rates and infection rates......  and should be forthcoming with the info. Good luck, tough decision... the good thing about a PICC is you could always get it and then still wait and decide about getting a port.... you know, kind of see how it goes with the PICC, you might not mind it.  That's what happened to my friend..... Thinking of you - Joanne

Posts.Title: freaking out Lisa40 TripleNeg

Posts.Content: joanne1428 wrote: Today I had two units of blood transfused because my hemoglobin is so low. Because of space and crowding, they had to put me in a chair in the pediatric chemo unit, and because of the length of the day I was there the whole day. A boy the age of my youngest son - I would say 15 or 16 - was brought in his mom..... a brother and a man (dad? wasn't sure) arrived, the dad watched the TV for 15 minutes, and then left. The mom left as soon as the dad arrived. That child was alone all day having chemo. By the end of the day he looked terrible, he was very nauseated and sick. He had two different times when they had to call the doctor and he had to deal with those visits all alone. I left when the unit was closing at 4:30 and he was all still alone. Maybe there was a very good reason that it all happened this way, but I found it very, very very sad. And there I sat, a 46 yr old woman, and who was beside me all day, keeping me company??? - my MOM....it is in these moments that I feel "lucky" even though I have Stage IV cancer...... Terrible enough that children get cancer, just so much more terrible to have a treatment alone. My kids are either teenagers or recent teen "graduates"... I know teens don't want to be smothered by their parents, but I also know that they need their parents still, even if that means from the next room! They still need them there. Just needed to share......... I came home and gave my boys an extra hug...... if you have teenagers, please go and give them that hug that little boy I saw today should have had from his mom or dad. My hopes are not always realized but I always hope - Ovid Dx 4/2006, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/33 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2007 11:08PM joanne1428 wrote: I had Cisplatin + Gemzar as first line tx for lung mets.  Cisplatin is a "cousin" to Carboplatin, both drugs are the platinum family, and they are apparently a very good option for soft tissue mets. In my case the Cisplatin was a little tough (nausea, fatigue) but the Gemzar was "easy"..... hair loss was minimal..... my blood counts would drop and I needed a dose reduction, but otherwise very tolerable. I had an excellent initial response (partial) to this combo for my lung mets.....  and then they stayed stable for another couple months.... then it stopped working completely.....   then it was on to another chemo..... I also had numerous spots, so surgery or RFA was not possible..... Many people have an even better result than I did.... I think you will find you have success with this combo..... I just hope it is brutal on those spots, and that it keeps them away for a LONG, LONG, time!!!! Joanne s

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 07:51PM - edited Oct 8, 2007 07:51PM by joanne1428 I am so sorry your scans turned out this way, and I am glad you came back here to tell us, and to allow us to help you through.  This is awful news for any of us and it arrives with a terrible shock.  If I could suggest anything, it would be to allow yourself a couple of days to let this all sink in, and to begin to get the opinion(s) so that you can get a treatment plan in place.  Bone mets are very treatable, as are other mets as well.  You will read some real "miracle" stories, right here on this board.   So even at the depths of your current despair, just try to remember that there is hope.  You don't have to believe it just yet, just believe that it might be possible, and the reality of that will unfold before you when you get over all this shock. As for your husband (and positive thinking):  Well, I think that he is wrong.  Positive thinking is great, and helps us have a better life.  But it alone will not treat this disease.  And, yes, it sure helps get us through treatment, but we need a lot more concrete support as well.  Like having someone to listen to us cry in those "not so positive" moments.   You've just been given a diagnosis that makes your cancer a part of your life forever - at best it will be managed as a chronic disease, at "worst" this disease  can be fatal.  It is impossible (in my opinion) to be positive all of the time.  Trying to keep up that kind of "Positive at all costs" face, takes a high price.   So if you are not feeling all that positive right now, you are completely normal.  Believe it or not, you will regain equilibrium and you will learn to live with this disease.  And if you were positive before, I am sure you will be again.....  but you also deserve to have any emotion known to man when you land in this kind of quagmire.   So, I hope you will allow yourself ALL of your feelings, it's part of learning to carry on with this dreadful disease. Hang on and keep posting.  We will try to keep you surrounded with love and support to help you get through this next while.   Joanne

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2007 02:48PM joanne1428 wrote: People are quick to make judgement, and I'm afraid maybe I was a bit that way myself in the "olden" pre-bc days.   Now I try never to judge anything by appearances, because you never know the true story. Last time I flew, my feet were very sore from HFS, so I decided to preboard so I could walk slowly to the seat.  It was that or use a wheelchair, and I decided I'd rather not do that rigamarole.  Anyway, the person taking the tickets was very snitty to me and made the comment about "this is preboarding only", and I kept my voice low, said "I fully realize that.  I do need extra time getting to my seat, and if you would like to check your manifest, you will see that there is a notation on my file to provide me with extra assistance"........  Shut her up, but I really hope she learned something.   And I found it very humiliating..... Sigh........
Posts.Title: Do I have to look disabled? Fllorik Fllorik

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2007 06:24AM joanne1428 wrote: Yes, I have a couple of people like this in my life, on my in-law side (very fortunate that my direct relatives have been totally wonderful and supportive). I have come to believe that these types of responses are from fear (they don't want bc themselves) and immaturity (unable to rise above their fear to be helpful) and a supreme lack of self-awareness (to recognize how their words or beliefs affect someone else).  My inlaws believe that I gave myself cancer by working outside the home.  That I would be bettter off if I was "open minded" to every quacky thing that they think cured their friend, neighbour etc (who have totally different types of cancer by the way).   They also have a number of reasons that they do not help out at all.  (we have lots of others to do that, I'm not able to "host" them - i.e. cook and clean for them)...... I think say these things to protect themselves from the reality that what happened to me is frightening and could happen to anyone.  I was stage 1, node negative, no bc risk factors, have done all the treatments, and I am still struggling with lung mets.    It's easier for them to blame me than to face their fear and really try to do something that might help us, but would be hard.  I don't cope with it very well, to be honest.  I try to get my social worker and music therapist to help me because they are literally the most toxic relationship that I have, and it is very hard. In the end, we have to safeguard our own well-being, and keep those who are damaging us in a place where they can do us less harm.  I'm not just sure what that is....  when I am really vulnerable for example, I try not to speak with them, let my husband do the talking. That sort of thing.  In the end, I am sorry you are having this type of reaction from people that you love.... you deserve more.  I hope that they "wake up" and offer you better support. Joanne

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2007 07:13PM joanne1428 wrote: I had this show up 3 yrs after my original Stage 1 diagnosis.  I am also triple negative.   I also had a wide area excision, then a whole bunch of radiation, then chemo.  The rest of me was fully scanned, but was "No Evidence of Disease". I did a lot of research (most of which  you should ignore because it is so old and outdated) but it is important for you to know that it is possible to go on from a local recurrence and never have it spread any further than that. Unfortunately, that is not my story.  I did go on to develop mets.....But I did get a wonderful 2 +years from chest wall recurrence to lung mets diagnosis.  I know that seems incredibly cold comfort, however, that's just my story, and I seem to have drawn the short straw on this one. Just remember that each breast cancer story is unique.  Many women have successful treatment for chest wall recurrence and never see another cancer cell.  That could be you, and since that is the case, why not just believe that will be you. Still, I understand the devastation you must be feeling.  It took me a long time to get back on my "feet" after the chest wall recurrence was diagnosed.  It just seems so unfair and so very frightening.  I wish you peace and good luck as you journey through this detour on your path....... Joanne
Posts.Title: Reccurence lali mkl48

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2007 04:11PM joanne1428 wrote: Yes, Lali, the signature refers to the mets diagnosis in 2006.  My original was 2001 and chest wall recurrence was 2004.  Yes, hope and fight.....  I know the statistics look grim, but why not just decide that you will be in the 20% - I know it doesn't necessarily work that way, but it will bring you more peace along the way. That is what happened to me.  I was 39 at initial diagnosis, and 43 for chest wall recurrence.  46 now.   My children also need me, and I am devastated that they will now lose their mother, it brings me no end of grief and suffering.  But, I can honestly say that I have tried my absolute best to do everything possible to "fight" this beast.....  and that is what we MUST do, it does not good to succomb to the despair that you might feel when looking at the stats alone.   When I had the chest wall recurrence.  I think I finally realized that I was not really in control of what was going to happen with my cancer.  I find peace by doing absolutely everything I can, treatment wise.  Good luck, hang on, and try to keep your hope alive.  And don't dwell too much on Susan Love..... those stats are outdated, and some experts cite much better odds.....  the thinking on chest wall recurrence after mastectomy is really changing.  I sincerely wish that when you have finished all the treatment for this, that will be the last you ever have to deal with cancer again.  AND remember, it could happen that way, so why not??? Thinking of you - Joanne

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2007 01:05AM joanne1428 wrote: Thank you all for your kind words, it brings tears to my eyes to see your loving support. Just a scheduling mix up had me without a chemo chair, because I was between chemos and next steps would depend on the CT, I had nothing booked, and the Christmas season was just impossible for them to squeeze me in when I wanted..... Anyway, my husband immediately told me he was relieved with my decision.  My 21 yr old said "solid call, mom" and when I expressed my disappointment that I would not be as lively as I would like, she said "I'd rather have alive than lively"....  Whoosh, and I'm crying, I foolishly assumed they'd rather have "normal" times, and they are actually more comforted that tx was not delayed.  Go figure. So, it is alreay done, I had Taxotere on Friday.   I had Taxotere in 2004 and it is considered successful because I had more than a year disease free interval, so worth giving a try, we'll see how it goes. ANd yes, you all remember me well.  I'm the one who took a big tumble in June and have been crawing my way back to anything since then.  It's so weird, I'm now getting pretty good CT results, but the damage done to me when I figured I was a goner in June is proving to be a tough recovery.  Funny thing, I promise you all.... I've been held in a limbo of sorts, here in my hospital bed/wheelchair/morphine/oxygen/palliative nursing, the works.  You would think it would be constant depression, but it is not.  I do hate all the chemo, but I have learned that you can still live a very joyful and happy life even within some very narrow confines.  I still get to be a mom to my kids, yes, it is a different way, but I am still here to listen to their ups and downs, encourage them, and remind my youngest that it's time to get in the shower.  I wouldn't have ever predicted it.  But now I know why people fight to the end.  It's just to keep having more "normal" and more time to say "I love you" to everyone and anyone you want! Thanks again for your love and good wishes and prayers, apparently I am still in need of those, I'm still waiting for my miracle! Joanne

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2007 02:03PM joanne1428 wrote: What I was told is that despite the instinctive appeal of stem cell transplants (it just seems like a good idea)... in breast cancer, the results have not proven to be any better than just using standard chemotherapies alone......  and because they are SO tough on the body, docs just stopped doing them. Still, you do hear of the miracle stories as a result, and I do believe that some people achieve that from the transplant, even if the odds of it are low.... Unfortunately, in my own personal life, I have known just one person who had one - she travelled quite a distance to find someone to do it, and it was not a good thing.   It is very hard to say if she lived any longer because of it, but she did suffer through major side effects of the procedure during her final months of life - not sure what was from the transplant, and what was just from advanced cancer.  So, I really don't know what I think.    IF is works it would be a miracle and super joyous, if it doesn't, it is not that pleasant to go through....  It's a good thing for us to discuss though.  I'd love to know more about it.

Posts.Content: joanne1428 wrote: Well, I think this is a reasonable result, although certainly not as good as others are getting, I'm still going to take it with gratitude! My CT of this week, when compared to October 31/07 showed "mostly" stable.  The good news is that there is still only lung and mediastinel nodes, no new sites or spread, no new nodules, and no new fluid.   The "not so good" news is that two of the exiting nodules - one in my left lower lung, and one in the hilar region (mediastinel node) showed slight growth each. So, it is not enough growth to be called "progression" officially, but it does give a warning bell about where things are headed!  The plan WAS to start a new regime after Christmas.... Oh, I was so excited to get Christmastime chemo free.......  that is I was excited for about 15 minutes, because that's when it became clear that there was no way I could be booked into chemo until mid-January, which my oncologist felt was waiting too long..... My choice then - get squeezed in TODAY or wait until mid-January.  (or hope for a cancellation just after Christmas, when I wanted the treatment).  So I took the "safe" way out, and had the treatment today.......  not crazy about having side effects of tx or Neupogen during the season, but it was my choice, so I will not complain further.  So, that's my news!  Wishing BETTER news for the rest of you! Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 12:07PM joanne1428 wrote: I am a big believer in exercise and adequate sleep/rest to keep our immune system strong.  And, if it becomes compromised, there is evidence that taking a multi-vitamin daily can improve immune response in the short term. As far as whether any of that prevents the cancer cells from developing, I think that is a bit of a mystery.  However, I think it is good to stay in the best physical health we can while undergoing cancer treatment, and "back to basics" is what I think is the most significant thing.  The kinds of things Grandma told you to do, that's my current thing.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2007 04:05PM - edited Oct 1, 2007 04:05PM by joanne1428 My advice is to find all possible places of resources to help with coping..... social workers or therapists at your clinic, as well as friends and families.   Of course, we have to find a way to live in the present but I also think this is a hard task to do alone.  Many clinics have wonderful resource people who really can help, and who are willing to face any of out fears without downplaying them. I think I'm pretty much like the rest of us.   I cope because I have to, what choice is there..... the challenge is to figure out how, we have to continue to go on to live, to love, to laugh, and to keep some kind of balance between the reality of our situation and hope.  I'm triple negative, not a lot of treatment options, and they have not gone spectacularly well.  But I still try to live with a balance of reality and hope.  Kudos to you for speaking.  I am sure you will be a lifeline to many.  Joanne S

Posts.Content: joanne1428 wrote: Well, it has been a challenging season for me, and my physical ability has been really limited.  I also found the family gatherings so emotional, as I said good bye to my well loved aunts and uncles and cousins, sister, nieces, etc....   I couldn't help wonder if it really was a final goodbye.... so I usually ended up slithering away at my time to go home, trying to say goodbye as little as possible.......  ANYWAY..... I do have a wonderful holiday highlight.....  I know your life really sucks when the best part of your holiday is also morbid, but two nights ago, my 21 year old daughter climbed into my (hospital) bed in the middle of the night, kind of like toddlers do..... and wanted to tell me that she was glad she had me for a mother and that it was better to have me for less of her life, than to never have had me for a mother at all.   It resulted in uncontrollable weeping (me, of course), but was the best gift I could have received. Thought I'd share a jewel in my pile of muck,  I've had a hard time with all the sad news lately... . and wanted to tell you that even in the depths of the valley, there are stupendous moments. Joanne P.S....     On a shallower note, I have eaten like a queen and have not cooked or done dishes for anything, I guess that's kind of bonus when compared to every other year of my life !!!!!! Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2007 01:09PM joanne1428 wrote: Well, I am giving you biased advice from my experience, so remember that. Unless you onc can really explain why he is not worried (ie. something about the appearance of those nodules must seem very benign), I don't think I would let the matter rest, and that is mostly because when you have single solitary nodules (and if, god forbid they turn out to be cancer) you have some treatment options that do not exist once lung mets are extensive.  Such as surgery or ablation, etc.. Myself, I think I would want a second opinion and at the least a rescan in 3 months.  I have benign nodules in my liver, and no one has ever been alarmed due to their appearance.... I now get CTs about every 3 months to monitor my lung mets, and they have never changed, definitely benign.... so your doctor is right, odds are in your favour for benign.  I just think I would want to be on the "safe" side and get it checked sooner rather than later.  My lung mets were also discovered on routine CT scan, but they were already diffuse.  I'm triple negative and so chemo has been my only option.....  But there are ladies who have solitary nodules removed and are doing well years and years and years later.... In the end, it is you that must have peace with whatever you decide, and of course, you will find support here no matter what that is.....  I think your onc must be pretty confident they are B9, but you just don't want to be the one oddball where the "look" doesn't match the reality. Best of luck - Joanne

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2007 01:06PM joanne1428 wrote: To Joel.... for myself....  when in treatment just the thought of sex is overwhelming, and right now (to be perfectly blunt) I don't have the breathing capacity for it either.....  So if my husband (or I) were to feel unloved as a result of not having sex, it just wouldn't make SENSE, although I realize that all feelings are not logical. Right now I'm in bad shape due to cancer.  However, my husband and I are extraordinarily close to each other, and we have to be happy with that for the time being.  I think it is just a result of staring death in the face and having to deal with the reality of that.  We've had converstations with each other that leave no doubt about the depth of love and devotion we feel for each other..... but sex has not been a part of that.... I wish it were still a possibility but so far I am just to weak and too unwell.    The amount of support I've had from him on this topic alone has stunned me, I expected a certain amount of support from him, but he has been kind and loving about it.  Also, good chance there isn't as much desire to be having sex with a clearly sick person. Now..... on the other hand, if you are finished treatment and recovering - physically and emotionally, I think there is where a lot of challenges with sex come in, for both partners.....and I think that lack of interest in sex might well be viewed as rejection by either gender, unless there was a whole lot of communicating and understanding going on.....  With  my first and second round with cancer, I felt I was never going to get my sex life back - but I did and I must say it was actually better than pre breast cancer....  but it is a process of healing, just like the other aspects of healing... Angel - hang on, there are good suggestions out there that might help you and don't be afraid to speak to your doctor or oncologist, they have a few tricks up their sleeves to help with the physical parts...... if it is more an emotional barrier, then a therapist can help get you past that part too.  Things will improve Angel, but it can take time, and patience!!!! Joanne

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2008 09:48PM joanne1428 wrote: Yes, this is not something to feel guilty about.  The pathology is usually rechecked, just as precaution, but the actual incidence of tumors "switching" is very very rare.... more commonly a 'switch' in pathology might indiate another primary, as katbob as said...... and the only bonus is that it gives mpre treatment options for that particular tumor.  I am triple negative all the way.  How I wish there were more options..   I see them coming though, I think the research is going to uncover somthing usable to the mainstream within a few years.... just not quite ready to help the masses right now..... In the meantime,we need to try to find ourselves a clinical trial, and we need to NOT beat ourselves up over something we cannot control. Joanne

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2007 02:10PM joanne1428 wrote: Thank you all ladies... what I should tell you is that my daughter (indeed, a lovely girl) is quite an ordinary kid.  What is really amazing is that she has spent most of the years since my diagnosis mad, sad, frightened and sometimes really unreasonable.  We've worked so hard with her, and finally she started counselling at the cancer clinic.  So for me, this was really so incredible.  I worry about her almost the most, because she is such a "drama queen" about most things...  this holiday season has been like watching a butterfly emerge from the gooey mess of the coccoon...... okay, well maybe not that perfect, but it sounded very poetic as I wrote it.... Even a few months ago, she resented having to help me do anything because she didn't want me to need help (does that make sense?) and she would still try to get me to do things for HER to prove to herself that I was still there for her.  I had given up expecting to feel any peace at all about her and yet, here it is, I get a glimmer....... Anyway, thanks to all of you !
